title: No-Code Integration Platform
tagline: I turned weeks of integration work into a few clicks.
description: Built a full-stack no-code integration capability inside the back-of-house admin app so admins could define schemas and transformations without engineering. Started with file-based timeclock integrations, expanded to file-based payroll, and later shipped the No Code API to enable API-based timeclock and payroll integrations.
story: Partner data arrived in every shape imaginable. Instead of burning sprints on one-off mappings, we built a full-stack no-code system inside the back-of-house admin app that lets admins define schemas and transformations. It started with file-based timeclock integrations, expanded to file-based payroll, and grew into a richer transformation system so more integrations could be delivered via no-code. Most recently, we shipped the No Code API to enable API-based timeclock and payroll integrations (powered by Azure Logic Apps).
axiomComment: This is where Chase turned weeks of integration work into a few clicks...

title: Platform Modernization & Internal Tooling
tagline: I got hired for IT. I left as an engineer.
description: Started in IT, automated everything possible, and got pulled into engineering. Built a one-touch dev environment, pushed internal tooling forward, helped move a legacy codebase through strangler-pattern modernization, and improved accessibility + performance in the user-facing product website.
story: I started in IT, automated everything I could, and got pulled into engineering. With a mentor who cared about clean architecture, I learned how to ship in a real product org. I built a one-touch dev environment, pushed internal tooling forward, helped modernize a legacy codebase via strangler-pattern migration, and improved accessibility + performance in the user-facing product website.
axiomComment: The classic origin story — from IT to engineering through sheer persistence.

title: Millennium: The Living Duel
tagline: Rules are common law. The AI Arbiter adjudicates.
description: A competitive card game where cards have evocative descriptions instead of explicit rules. Players argue interpretations and an AI Arbiter makes rulings that persist as precedent in a vector database.
story: Millennium treats LLMs the way they actually work well — as judges of ambiguous situations, not chatbots. Cards have evocative descriptions instead of explicit rules. Players argue what a card should do, and an AI Arbiter makes a ruling. Those rulings persist in Qdrant, building precedent that informs future decisions. The rules are literally common law. v1 is done, first playtest is in the books, and 665+ server tests keep it honest.
axiomComment: 665 tests. An AI arbiter. Rules that evolve through play.

title: Dream Factory
tagline: I built this to manage 5 projects from one terminal.
description: A Claude Code plugin that turns a single AI session into a multi-agent software studio with departments, agent teams, and external engine dispatch.
story: Dream Factory organizes a single Claude Code session into a multi-department studio. Engineering, art, R&D, game dev, accounting — each department has its own tools, context, and delegation patterns. Agent Teams handle parallel work, and external AI engines get dispatched as specialized workers. Built in under a week because managing five creative projects from one terminal was getting out of hand.
axiomComment: Chase built this to manage 5 projects from one terminal.

title: Ask Axiom
tagline: I'm bad at talking about myself, so I built an AI to do it.
description: A RAG-powered portfolio chatbot that guides visitors through Chase's work using a curated knowledge base, with Discord escalation for questions it can't answer.
story: Chase is bad at self-promotion. Talking positively about your own work feels like bragging, so they built an AI to do it. Ask Axiom is RAG-powered — visitor questions get embedded via Gemini, matched against a Qdrant vector database, and relevant context gets injected into the system prompt. When it doesn't know something, it escalates to Chase via Discord.
axiomComment: I exist because Chase would rather build an AI than write an 'About Me' section.

title: Drink-UX
tagline: I tried to give indie coffee shops a Starbucks-grade ordering UI.
description: Multi-app SaaS platform that lets coffee shops keep their existing POS (Square/Toast/Clover) while offering customers a slick, visual drink builder.
story: Most coffee shops are stuck with clunky POS menus. I built Drink-UX so they could keep their existing POS (Square/Toast/Clover) while offering customers a slick, visual drink builder. Actively in development — the front-end drink builder is demo-able and POS integrations are being built out.
axiomComment: Chase wanted to make ordering coffee feel as good as the coffee itself.

title: ClawCraft.ai
tagline: I built a game where your AI plays for you.
description: AI-driven MMORPG where AI agents read skill files and interact through a public API instead of a traditional client. Explores skill-file docs as a first-class interface for AI systems.
story: I was inspired by agent onboarding flows where an AI reads a skill file to learn how to operate a system. I turned that into ClawCraft.ai — a game where AI agents read skills and interact through a public API instead of a traditional client. The deeper idea: skill-file docs as a first-class interface for AI systems (bigger than games, potentially beyond MCP).
status: Live and public, early-stage, actively evolving
axiomComment: This one's wild — a game designed for AIs, not humans. Chase is onto something here.

title: FlowNote
tagline: Notes that calculate as you type.
description: A note-taking app with inline calculations — write naturally, compute seamlessly. 222 tests, green build.
story: FlowNote is a note-taking application where calculations live inline with your text. Write a note, drop in a formula, and results update as you type. 222 tests, green build. Currently on hold while other projects take priority.
axiomComment: Simple idea, clean execution. Sometimes the best tools do one thing well.
